metadata.sermon_title: Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory
metadata.sermon_start_end: A good friend of mine is rector of a church in the Massachusetts Berkshires. She tells a story about her husband and his Sunday school class. [...] The very glory of God shines in the face of Jesus of Nazareth. He dies and he shines for you. AMEN.
metadata.notes: Lenten Series sermon delivered at St. Paul’s Church, Richmond, Virginia.

logos.analysis: The sermon follows a thematic-exegetical structure, moving from the challenge of modern skepticism to the biblical motif of the 'cloud' across three testaments, concluding with the application of suffering. The rational architecture is functional but not rigorous. The preacher uses the lectionary readings as a scaffold, linking the Old Testament 'devouring fire' with the New Testament Transfiguration. However, the logical transitions between the intellectual problem of God's existence (the Guatemala massacre) and the liturgical theme of the Transfiguration are somewhat abrupt. The argument relies more on thematic recurrence (the cloud) than on a tight deductive chain. The conclusion that 'glory is hidden in suffering' is presented as a theological claim rather than a logically derived necessity from the preceding text analysis.
quotes: Three of the four contain the same motif; the Psalm, the Old Testament lesson, and the Gospel all speak of a cloud.
The images are a little confusing, aren’t they? First there’s a cloud, then there’s a fire. These are ways of saying that God’s presence is both visible and hidden.
For you see, the lectionary is designed so that the Transfiguration is the climactic event of revelation before the Passion of Jesus begins.
strengths: Effective use of a recurring biblical motif (the cloud) to unify disparate texts.
Clear explanation of the 'revealing while concealing' paradox in Hebrew scripture.
Logical placement of the Transfiguration within the wider narrative of the liturgical year.
improvement_points: Strengthen the causal link between the 'intellectual skepticism' introduced at the start and the 'theology of the cross' at the end.
Clarify the transition from the theodicy problem (Guatemala) back to the Transfiguration narrative.
Provide a more structured synthesis of the Philippians text with the previous three readings.
logos.specific_diagnosis: The Logos is sufficient for a thematic sermon but lacks the sharp, argumentative edge needed to fully answer the intellectual skepticism it raises in the introduction.

pathos.analysis: The sermon achieves significant emotional resonance by contrasting the 'brilliant white' of the Transfiguration with the 'pigsty' of human suffering. The preacher effectively uses sensory language—'burn the human cornea,' 'devouring fire,' 'bent and crippled by sin.' The inclusion of the Guatemala massacre serves as a high-pathos 'slice of life' that prevents the sermon from becoming a mere academic exercise. The emotional tone shifts appropriately from the 'sore afraid' terror of the disciples to the weary but resolute hope of Martin Luther King Jr. The appeal to the 'fear of the Lord' challenges the modern hearer's desire for a 'wishy-washy god,' touching on the existential need for a God strong enough to overcome real evil.
pathos.emotional_tone: Serious and somber, transitioning from existential dread to cruciform hope.
quotes: The leader of the scientific group showed evidence to a reporter, paused, and said, 'Poor little kids.' Where was God when that was happening?
The disciples were 'sore afraid.' Only the word and the touch of Jesus was able to restore them.
It was said afterward that never did a man seem less happy... Dr. King had been walking in the flames.
strengths: Strong use of concrete, jarring imagery (massacres, burning corneas) to create emotional weight.
Authentic engagement with the 'absence of God' which resonates with the hearer's own doubts.
Effective use of the Martin Luther King Jr. anecdote to ground the 'glory' in historical suffering.
improvement_points: The transition to the Guatemala story is so emotionally heavy it risks overshadowing the biblical exegesis.
Ensure the 'joy' of the Transfiguration is given enough affective space so the contrast with suffering is balanced.
Avoid the slight 'head-pathos' in the academic anecdotes (the Ivy League student) by making them more relatable to the average layperson.
pathos.specific_diagnosis: Strong Pathos that successfully bridges the gap between ancient text and modern tragedy, though it occasionally risks overwhelming the Logos.

ethos.analysis: The Ethos is the strongest element of this sermon. The preacher speaks as a 'witness' rather than a distant lecturer. She is remarkably vulnerable about her own struggles with doubt, stating that the 'scorn of intellectuals' is less troubling than the 'apparent inaction of God.' By identifying herself as 'bent and crippled by sin like all the rest of humanity,' she establishes a horizontal relationship with the congregation. Her authority is derived not from her clerical status—which she explicitly deconstructs—but from her long-term 'testing' of the scriptures in the 'struggles and doubts' of her own life. The mention of her ministry in the Northeast and her interactions with skeptical intellectuals adds a layer of lived-in credibility.
ethos.authenticity: High; the preacher positions herself as a fellow-traveler in doubt and a witness to the truth through suffering.
quotes: I have been many years coming to this point, but I believe that Christian discipleship requires that we let people know that we do believe the story.
Frankly, the scorn of intellectuals doesn’t bother me half as much as the apparent inaction of God in so much of daily life.
Any preacher who does not suffer in bringing you the gospel is no Christian messenger.
strengths: Exceptional vulnerability regarding the difficulty of faith in a skeptical age.
Rejection of 'clerical distance' in favor of a shared human struggle.
Authority is grounded in the 'testing' of the Word rather than dogmatic assertion.
improvement_points: The anecdote about the Ivy League student could be perceived as slightly elitist if not careful.
Ensure the personal 'I' does not overshadow the 'He' of the gospel in the final application.
Maintain the balance between 'witness' and 'teacher' to ensure the congregation still feels led by a capable guide.
ethos.specific_diagnosis: The Ethos is exemplary; the preacher’s credibility is built on honesty, vulnerability, and a refusal to offer easy answers.

rhetorical_balance_analysis.analysis: The sermon is a 'Witnessing-Visionary' piece where the credibility of the speaker (Ethos) and the emotional weight of the message (Pathos) carry the weight that a more traditional sermon might place on logical argumentation (Logos). The balance is effective for a Lenten series where existential reflection is prioritized over dogmatic instruction. The Ethos reinforces the Pathos; because we trust the preacher's honesty about doubt, we are more moved by her descriptions of suffering. The Logos is the 'skeleton' that holds it together, but it is thin in places, particularly in the synthesis of the four different texts.
consequences_of_imbalance: Intellectually rigorous hearers might find the resolution of the 'theodicy' problem (Guatemala) logically unsatisfying.
The heavy reliance on Ethos means the sermon's power is highly dependent on the preacher's delivery and perceived sincerity.
The 'cloud' motif provides a poetic rather than a logical unity, which may leave some confused about the specific 'point' of the Exodus passage.
rhetorical_balance_analysis.recommendation_for_balance: Strengthen the Logos by more explicitly connecting the 'righteousness through faith' in the Philippians text to the 'cloud/fire' imagery of the earlier passages.

orthodoxy_logos.analysis: The sermon maintains high Christology (Incarnation, Divinity) and a classic Theology of the Cross, avoiding the pitfall of a purely 'moral' or 'exemplary' reading of Jesus.

orthopathy_pathos.analysis: The sermon successfully awakens a 'God-fearing joy'—a sense of awe that does not bypass the reality of fear and suffering.

orthopraxy_ethos.analysis: The preacher models the 'suffering messenger' she describes, presenting a life lived under the authority of the Word.

overall_picture.summary: This is a strong, credible sermon that excels in Ethos and Pathos. The preacher avoids the 'ivory tower' trap by leaning into the difficulty of belief in a secular, suffering world. By framing the Transfiguration not as a magical event but as a 'revealing while concealing' of divine glory in human suffering, she makes a difficult text accessible and existentially urgent. The sermon's greatest strength is its honesty; it does not try to 'solve' the problem of God's hiddenness but invites the hearer to trust the witness of those who have seen the glory in the midst of the fire. While the logical structure (Logos) is somewhat loose—functioning more as a series of reflections on a theme than a single driving argument—the cumulative effect is persuasive because of the preacher's evident integrity and the vividness of her imagery.
strengths_top_3: Authentic and vulnerable Ethos that builds immediate trust.
Vivid, sensory imagery that makes the biblical 'glory' and 'terror' palpable.
Effective use of historical and personal narrative to ground abstract theology.
improvement_points_top_3: Tighten the logical transitions between the various biblical texts.
Provide a more robust rational response to the intellectual skepticism raised in the intro.
Ensure the 'theodicy' section (Guatemala) is more fully integrated into the Christological conclusion.
overall_picture.audience_analysis: Most appealing to 'seekers' and 'struggling believers' who value authenticity over dogmatism; potentially less satisfying for those seeking systematic theological exposition.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with a more deductive structure to see if it can support the high Pathos.
Use fewer anecdotes to allow more space for deep exegetical 'digging'.
Continue to lean into the 'witness' role, as it is clearly the preacher's greatest rhetorical gift.
overall_picture.conclusion: Through the lens of the Rhetorical Triangle, this sermon is a model of how Ethos can provide the necessary foundation for Pathos. By presenting herself as a credible, suffering witness, the preacher earns the right to speak about the 'terrible' glory of God. While the Logos could be more robust, the sermon succeeds in its primary homiletical task: making the Gospel a lived experience rather than a dead doctrine. It is a 'good person speaking well,' whose words carry weight because they are backed by a visible, tested faith.
